Variation Example: The devil (ogre, bear) & a farmer (God, saint, Gypsy, fox) want to divide the crop. In the first year, the devil claims what grows above the ground. The farmer plants turnips (potatoes), & the devil only gets the greens. In the following year they want to divide the other way. The farmer sows wheat (other kinds of grain, cabbage) & the devil, who gets what is growing beneath the ground, again comes away empty-handed.

A clever & a foolish brother, who want to divide their livestock, build a new cow-shed: The foolish brother will get all animals which go into the new cow-shed, & the clever brother all those which go into the old one. Only one ox (usually old, blind, lame) goes into the new cow-shed.

Classifications: Granary Roof Used as Threshing Flail
Variation Example: A giant & his farmhand have a threshing contest. The giant’s iron threshing flails are too heavy for the farmhand to lift. So the farmhand pretends to use the barn roof (rafter) as threshing flail. The giant gives up.

An ogre (devil) asks his farmhand to clear out the manure. The farmhand digs a hole for the manure or piles it high. In some variants, the farmhand puts a cork in the ox’s backside to keep the stable clean, or he kills the animal for soiling itself.

The devil (giant, dragon) & a man (Gypsy) have a contest to see who is able to throw more hogs out of a stable (over a roof, fence). The man throws only one hog, the devil all the others. When they are about to divide the animals, the man pretends he can recognize the hogs he has thrown out by a sign: He had turned around their tails. Thus the man gets all hogs with curly tails, the devil only a sick one with a straight tail.

An ogre & a boy, who breed sheep & pigs, are going to divide what the animals produce. Of the sheep, the ogre gets the lambs to fatten, the boy gets the wool & the milk. Of the pigs, the boy gets the young ones, & the ogre is allowed to shear the pigs & take their milk. In a shorter version, an ogre (numskull, devil) tries to shear a pig & comments on this experience, “Much screaming, no wool”.

This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A man (workman, shepherd boy) threatens the devil (ogre) by pretending that he will pull together a lake (pull away a forest or mountains) with a rope (chain). The devil is intimidated (because he lives in the lake. He tries to kill the man, or gives him gold or other gifts to stop him). (2) A man threatens an ogre (devil) by pretending to pull away a warehouse with a rope. The ogre is intimidated by the man’s seeming power. (They tie a rope around the warehouse; the ogre pulls & is crushed beneath the house.) (3) A man (farmhand) makes a long rope so he can lead home the whole herd of cattle.

A poor man (often the youngest of three brothers) becomes a farmhand of the devil (master, a red-haired man, God). The farmhand is ordered to get neither straight nor crooked wood, or semi-straight & semi-crooked wood, in equal parts (buy a forest). The farmhand cuts down the wood & thus does his master harm. The master discharges him immediately (gives him another order).

A master (ogre, devil, bear) asks his farmhand (boy, old man, tailor) to fetch firewood & water, but the axe & the buckets are so heavy that the farmhand cannot lift them. The farmhand demands an axe heavy enough to cut down the whole forest & a bucket large enough to bring in the whole well. The master is frightened & does the work himself.

An ogre (giant, devil, dragon, bear) & a man (boy, old man, Gypsy, tailor) each try to fell a large tree in order to see who is faster & stronger. The man exchanges the ogre’s axe with a dull one. In some variants, the man secretly saws into his tree in advance, uses an axe while the ogre uses his fists, or tricks the ogre into doing all the work.

An ogre (giant, devil, dragon, bear) & a man (Gypsy, tailor) have a contest to see who is the stronger. The man is not able to bend a tree & to keep the tree-top down. He tricks the ogre into performing this task. When the tree-top springs up, the man is shot into the sky. He pretends to have made a high jump to fetch (catch) something. (The ogre is unable to imitate the jump, falls to his death, or gives up.)

An ogre (giant, devil, bear) & his helper (man, fox) are going to carry home the tree they have felled. The helper says that he is stronger (does not know the way) & will carry the top, while the ogre carries the bottom-end. The ogre goes first & carries the bot tom-end. But instead of carrying the branches, the helper sits on them, & the ogre has to carry the whole burden alone.
An ogre (giant) asks his farmhand to shoot a wild boar or two. The farmhand asks, “Why not a thousand at one shot?” The ogre is frightened by the presumed power of his farmhand
A farmer (boy) makes the devil ride on a reversed harrow (roller, sit on the thorny end of a tree)

An ogre (giant, devil) & a (poor) man (tailor, Gypsy) have a contest to see which of them can squeeze water out of a stone. The ogre squeezes a stone; the man a cheese (egg, turnip) & thus intimidates the ogre. (In some variants, the actors are animals.)
An ogre (giant) & a man (tailor, sailor) com-pete to determine whose handshake is stronger. The man wears an iron glove & wins. In some variants, the man holds out a (glowing) iron rod (fork, etc.).

An ogre (devil) & a man (boy, tailor, soldier) compete to see who can bite (bruise) a stone to pieces. The man takes a nut (pea) & bites it easily. The ogre, who is not able to bite the stone to pieces, is impressed by the man’s strong teeth. In some variants, a tailor must stay for a night in the stable with a bear. The tailor makes the bear curious by cracking nuts & then gives him stones, which the bear cannot crack.

An ogre (giant, devil, dragon) & a man (boy, tailor, Gypsy) compete to determine who can throw a stone higher: The one whose stone falls first to the ground will lose. The ogre throws a stone. The man throws a bird (sparrow, lark, bat), which never comes back

An ogre (giant, devil) & a man (boy) compete in throwing a (golden, heavy) club (hammer, axe) higher. The ogre throws the club up high. The man hesitates, pretending to wait for a cloud to throw the club into (takes care not to hit a star, wants to throw the club up to a relative in heaven). The ogre gives up. In some variants, the man shows the ogre the club in a cloud, or he pretends that he had already thrown the club & it will not come back.

An ogre (giant) & a man have a throwing contest. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The man pretends to throw a stone (rock) so far that it will destroy a village (house) beyond the sea (mountains), or he warns Angel Gabriel (St. Peter) to look out. (2) The man pretends that he will throw a stone to a distant point (Constantinople) where it will strike one of the ogre’s relatives.

Classifications: Making Fire by Stamping on the Ground
Variation Example: An ogre (giant) & a (timid , old) man have a contest: They want to make fire (get water) by stamping on the ground. The man wins the contest because he pre pared hot ashes beforehand (buried a tube filled with water in the earth), & thus he intimidates the ogre.

An ogre (giant, magician, dragon, demon, bear) & a man (Gypsy, famous wrestler) have a wrestling contest. The ogre squeezes the man so hard that his eyes bulge out. When the ogre asks him why he is staring, the man answers that he is looking for where to throw him. The ogre gives up (flees, promises money, swears eternal friendship).
An ogre (giant, devil) challenges a man (boy, farmer) to a wrestling contest. The man sends his “grandfather” (“brother”, “uncle”) – a bear – instead. The ogre loses.
An ogre (giant) challenges a man to a race. The man persuades the ogre to run against his little son – a rabbit – instead of himself. The rabbit wins.
An ogre (giant) challenges a man to a climbing contest. The man persuades the ogre to compete with the man’s child – a squirrel – instead of himself. The squirrel wins.

Classifications: Race Won by Deception: Relatives as Helpers
Variation Example: An ogre (giant, devil) challenges a man (a man challenges an animal) to a race. The man places his relatives (others that resemble him) along the course (at the finish). The ogre thinks that the man is just ahead of him (has won).
An ogre (giant) & a man have a laughing contest. The man puts a dead horse with a grinning mouth in his place. The ogre tries to laugh as long as the horse, & laughs till he dies.

An ogre (giant, devil) & a man (Gypsy, shoe-maker) take turns in carrying a horse. The ogre carries it on his back & is soon exhausted. The man takes the horse between his legs, i.e. rides, & thus “carries” it without effort.

The devil (monk) & a man (soldier) come to an agreement: While one of them sings a song, the other must carry him on his back. The dev il’s song is short. The man, however, sings an endless song (continuously sings the same song). The devil gives up (bursts).

The devil (ogre, giant) & a (poor) man (smith, teacher, Gypsy, God, old woman) duel in a little room (stable, fold, forest). The man gives the devil a long pole & chooses a short cudgel (hammer) for himself. The devil cannot do anything with his pole, so the man beats him up. (After this, they continue the duel outside, but exchange weapons. So the man beats the devil up again.

The devil & a man want to fight. The devil has a bayonet (sword, pike), & the man has a pitchfork. The man threatens that he will inflict five wounds on the devil with each thrust, while the devil himself can give him only one wound. Therefore the devil wants to exchange weapons. The man stands behind a fence so that the devil cannot hit him.

An ogre (giant, devil) & a man (boy) have a screaming (whistling) contest. The man binds up his head to prevent it from breaking in two when he screams. The ogre is frightened & begs the man to bind up his head, too. The man does so & then strikes him on his head. The ogre acknowledges the man to be the stronger. In some variants, the man blindfolds the ogre & strikes him with a hammer on his head (forehead).

Classifications: Making a hole in a tree
Variation Example: An ogre (giant) & a man have a contest to see who can make a deeper hole in a tree with his head (fist). The man wins because he already had prepared the tree beforehand: He had cut a hole with his axe & replaced the bark. In some variants, the actors are animals.

An ogre (giant, devil) & a man (boy, Gypsy) have a contest to see who can jump deeper into the ground (can get the earth’s bowels out). The man wins because he has dug a pit beforehand & covered it with boughs or a mat (buried fish guts in the ground).

An ogre orders a man to row him to go fishing. The man tells him that he will break the oars. The ogre then rows him self. In some variants, the rowing contest is won by deception: The boat has already been sawn through.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) An ogre (giant) & a man (boy) have an eating contest. The man slips his food (drink) into a concealed bag (behind his shirt) & makes the ogre believe he is the bigger eater. In many versions the hero cuts open the bag to eat even more; the ogre imitates & kills himself. (2) The devil (giant) & a man have a drinking contest. The man drinks water, the devil is given alcohol (vinegar, vitriol). The devil feels sick & acknowledges the man as the better drinker.

The devil (ogre, giant) & a (poor) man have a threshing contest. The man has a wooden flail, the devil one of iron. The old & weak man accomplishes less than the devil. When they finally divide the result, the devil chooses the big heap of chaff, while the man gets the smaller heap of grain.

The devil (ogre, giant) & a man (smith, farmer, boy) have a mowing contest. (The man takes the center of the field.) The devil is given a dull sickle (and he mows around the outside of the field, tiring himself out). In some variants, during the night the man secretly prepares the part of the meadow the devil has to mow the next day: He sticks harrow-tines (teeth) among the grass. Thus the devil’s scythe becomes chipped, & the man wins the contest.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The devil (dragon, death, bear) & a man make a deal (contest) to see who can present (after a certain space of time) a horse un like any other. (The devil puts a mask on a sheep, but the man recog  nizes it.) The man brings his wife, naked but covered with tar & feathers (hair combed over her face), on hands & knees with her but tocks as the head. The devil has never seen such a horse & is defeated. (2) Like (1) with the difference, that the man is to present an un known game animal. He brings his wife covered with tar & feathers & pretends to shoot her.

Classifications: Guessing the Name of the Devil's Secret Plant
Variation Example: The devil plants tobacco & asks a man who is unfamiliar with this plant to guess its name. (The devil threatens to kill him if he does not succeed.) The man’s wife, covered with tar & feathers, approaches the plant (ruins part of the field), so that the devil orders the supposed animal to get away from his tobacco. Thus the name of the plant is discovered.
